comments:
after starting weblogic server 9.2 mp1 from within eclipse sdk 3.2.2 
build M20070212-1330 for solaris gtk, something in the wtp system programatically requests weblogic server 9.2 to shut itself down 
only seconds after the server is started. 


steps to reproduce:

1. download & install eclipse sdk 3.2.2 build M20070212-1330 for solaris (eclipse-SDK-3.2.2-solaris-gtk.zip)

     http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/R-3.2.2-200702121330/

2. update eclipse sdk with the Web Tools Platform (WTP) 1.5.3 plus all of the WTP 1.5.3 pre-reqs:
 
       http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/downloads/drops/R1.5/R-1.5.3-200702082048/

3. download & install bea weblogic server 9.2 mp1 binary package installer for solaris 9 sparc:

   http://commerce.bea.com/showallversions.jsp?family=WLS

4. confirm that bea weblogic server's sample domain can be started from the solaris 9's shell:

   $ $BEA_HOME/weblogic92/samples/domains/workshop/startWebLogic.sh

5. create a j2ee enterprise application by following the instructions in the following WTP tutorial:

    http://www.eclipse.org/webtools/community/tutorials/BuildJ2EEWebApp/BuildJ2EEWebApp.html

    a. in the "Choose a Server Runtime Environment" step, choose BEA WebLogic 9.2 server
         instead of Tomcat.

6. start the generic bea weblogic server v9.2.1 from the servers view as instructed in the tutorial.

the eclipse status bar in the bottom right hand corner of eclipse indicates that weblogic server 9.2 is starting. eclipse then switches focus from the servers view to the console view. the console view lists the typical weblogic server startup console entries:

...
...<Server state changed to STANDBY> 
...<Server state changed to STARTING>
...<No test table set up for pool "cgDataSource". Connections will not be tested.> 
...<No test table set up for pool "cgDataSource-nonXA". Connections will not be tested.> 
...<No test table set up for pool "samplesDataSource". Connections will not be tested.> 
... [see 13_05_07_eclipse_wls_startup.txt in comment #1 attachment for full console output]

eventually - but only for a few seconds - the servers view indicates the state of the weblogic server as "Started". the following log entries snipped from weblogic server 9.2's filesystem logs confirm that the wls did actually start at some point:

...
...<Server state changed to RUNNING> 
...<Server started in RUNNING mode> 
...<78% of the total memory in the server is free> 
... [see cgServer.log in comment #1 attachment for full log output]

then eclipse automatically switches focus to the console view again; displaying 
the following:

========================================================================
$BEA_HOME/weblogic92/samples/domains/workshop/bin/stopWebLogic.sh:  

Stopping Weblogic Server...

Initializing WebLogic Scripting Tool (WLST) ...

Welcome to WebLogic Server Administration Scripting Shell

Type help() for help on available commands

Connecting to t3://localhost:7001 with userid weblogic ...
This Exception occured at Sun May 13 12:35:42 BST 2007.
javax.naming.CommunicationException [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: t3://localhost:7001: Destination unreachable; nested exception is: 
	java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused; No available router to destination]
...[see 13_05_07_eclipse_wls_shutdown.txt in comment #1 attachment for full stack trace]

========================================================================

the servers view eventually indicates the server has transitioned to the "Stopped"  state. the problem is, i never commanded neither eclipse or wls to shutdown the wls server. 

since the wls server can be successfully started outside of eclipse from the shell, and since - once it is successfully started outside of eclipse - wls doesn't automatically shutdown as soon as it starts; i suspect there is something in eclipse|wtp that is triggering the automatic shutdown.

i encounter this exact same bug using wls 9.0 with eclipse 3.2.2/wtp 1.5.3 on solaris 9 sparc (which is what prompted me to upgrade to wls 9.2 on solaris 9 sparc; see bug #169197); and i encounter this exact same bug with wls 9.2 with eclipse 3.2.2/wtp 1.5.3 in mac os x 10.4.9! in all cases, i have done nothing more and nothing less than what the eclipse/wtp and weblogic documentation has instructed me to do. 

please, provide a fix or a workaround. thanks in advance.

be thrown at a different point (when a wldeploy.xml ant script
is executed; not at the point of "Initializing WebLogic
Scripting Tool (WLST)" like in the solaris installation):

 [wldeploy] weblogic.Deployer invoked with options:  -debug -verbose -noexit -name WTP_WebApp_Tutorial -source /Users/bilbo/development/projects/eclipse_3.2.2_tutorial/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.wst.server.core/tmp0/WTP_WebApp_Tutorial -adminurl t3://localhost:7001 -user weblogic -deploy

 [wldeploy] java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused; No available router to destination. Ensure the url represents a running admin 
...
[see "13_05_07_wst_1.5.4_mac_os_x_wldeploy_echos.txt" in the attachment for the full stack trace]

=====================================================

also, on the mac the cgServer.log has the following additional log entries which didn't appear in the solaris cgServer.log:


=====================================================

...<Graceful shutdown of cgServer was issued remotely from 10.0.0.9>

thanks in advance for any other suggestions you can think of. 

btw, in case you were gonna suggest updating to a newer version of eclipse: i downloaded and installed an integration build for solaris sparc gtk a couple days ago (eclipse-SDK-I20070508-0800). i updated that integration build by adding wst 2.0 plus its pre-reqs. and it doesn't even display the j2ee perspective! also, wst 2.0 for eclipse-SDK-I20070508-0800 does not provide an option to download the bea weblogic 9.2 server in the "download new server runtime" wizard (or whatever its called). there also aren't any options to create j2ee projects. what's up with that? do i need to file a bug for that too? or has there already been one filed?

many thanks,
sun-certified
Assigning to Rob since he appears to have been the lead on most WLS server adapter bugs in 1.5.x.
*** Bug 169197 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I do not have immediate access to a Solaris environment but just tried the scenario on Windows to determine if this is a general issue with 1.5.4 and WLS - it is not (the issue did not repro).

The following IOException is included in the both Solaris logs:

...
!ENTRY org.eclipse.debug.core 4 120 2007-05-13 12:36:32.645
!MESSAGE Error logged from Debug Core: 
!STACK 0
java.io.IOException: Stream closed
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.getBufIfOpen(BufferedInputStream.java:145)
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read1(BufferedInputStream.java:253)
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read(BufferedInputStream.java:313)
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read1(BufferedInputStream.java:254)
	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read(BufferedInputStream.java:313)
	at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(FilterInputStream.java:90)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.OutputStreamMonitor.read(OutputStreamMonitor.java:138)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.OutputStreamMonitor.access$1(OutputStreamMonitor.java:128)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.OutputStreamMonitor$1.run(OutputStreamMonitor.java:194)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:595)
...

I believe this reflects the following sequence of events:

-ExternalLaunchConfigurationDelegate.launch() is creating an org.eclipse.debug.core.model.RuntimeProcess object for the java.lang.Process object that is created when the startWeblogic.* script is launched.

-RuntimeProcess creates a StreamsProxy object that monitors the process streams

-One of the OutputStreamMonitors (for either the InputStream or ErrorStream) is failing to get created with that error.

-This error is causing creation of the RutimeProcess object to fail and triggering automatic shutdown of the server instance.

I also noticed in the Eclipse log for the other bug the following: 

...
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.filesystem 1 1 2007-03-15 13:15:28.606
!MESSAGE Could not load library: liblocalfile_1_0_0.so.  This library provides platform-specific optimizations for certain file system operations.  This library is not present on all platforms, so this may not be an error.  The resources plug-in will safely fall back to using java.io.File functionality.
...

I am not familiar with Solaris or the Eclipse packaging for this OS so do not know for certain if a liblocalfile should be available (I suspect it should...); this error may indicate a problem with the Eclipse build/installation.

The mac issue looks distinct (can you verify that the configured admin URL of t3://localhost:7001 for the server instance is valid)

Given all of this, I suspect that something platform-specific (or installation/configuration specific) is happening in this case and am going to drop this from blocker to critical. 

Can you answer/try a few things for me:

-are you able to successfully launch external Java processed from your Eclipse instance? (e.g. another Eclipse instance)
-are you able to successfully use any other WTP server adapters?
cancel the interpretation of that stack: it is not failing during creation of the monitor but after the thread has been started; other questions still apply.

searching bugzilla for similar OS-related issues (search for "solaris gtk") did turn up some potentially related bugs (e.g. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=184403); if you try out that search and scan the issues to see if any of those might also apply to your installation (and therefore impact this issue), that would be much appreciated

OK, fairly certain the OS-dependency was a false lead it is better to focus instead and the standard reasons why this would happen: server start-up simply timed out (and the default behavior on timeout is to execute the "stop" logic for the server). 

The shutdown is either being called when a "timeout" is detected within PingThread.ping() or Server.start(); since you are getting a ConnectionException running stopWeblogic.sh, that indicates that perhaps nothing is listening on localhost:7001 (i.e. PingThread failed to successfully estabilish an HttpURLConnection to the server at http://localhost:7001 and, after the designated number of attempts, "stops" the server).

This is consistent with the WLS startup log you provided:

-the last server state I see is "STARTING" and I don't see an entry indicating it is listening on port 7001; i.e. I would expect to see entries like the following:

...
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "Default[2]" is now listening on 127.0.0.1:7001 for protocols iiop, t3, ldap, http.> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "DefaultSecure[1]" is now listening on 192.168.15.111:7002 for protocols iiops, t3s, ldaps, https.> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "Default" is now listening on 172.24.28.224:7001 for protocols iiop, t3, ldap, http.> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "DefaultSecure" is now listening on 172.24.28.224:7002 for protocols iiops, t3s, ldaps, https.> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "DefaultSecure[2]" is now listening on 127.0.0.1:7002 for protocols iiops, t3s, ldaps, https.> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "Default[1]" is now listening on 192.168.15.111:7001 for protocols iiop, t3, ldap, http.> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <WebLogicServer> <BEA-000331> <Started WebLogic Admin Server "examplesServer" for domain "wl_server" running in Development Mode> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <WebLogicServer> <BEA-000365> <Server state changed to RUNNING> 
<May 14, 2007 10:01:05 AM EDT> <Notice> <WebLogicServer> <BEA-000360> <Server started in RUNNING mode> 
...

I thought it was odd that this shutdown was happening after only a few seconds (the configured timeout duration for that server type is 120 seconds - longer than the standard for most of the other generic servers), however, your eclipse_wls_startup log has an initial time of <May 13, 2007 12:32:14 PM 
BST> and a last time of <May 13, 2007 12:34:11 PM BST>: about two minutes.

Are you experiencing equivalently slow startup times when you launch WLS independently?

I'm not clear why the server state was transitioning into "Started" before the shutdown (that call should be getting made by PingThread after a successful connection).

Your attempt with 1.5.4 fails due to the following:

FATAL ERROR in native method: JDWP No transports initialized, jvmtiError=JVMTI_ERROR_INTERNAL(113)
Stopping PointBase server...
PointBase server stopped.
ERROR: transport error 202: bind failed: Address already in use ["transport.c",L41]
ERROR: JDWP Transport dt_socket failed to initialize, TRANSPORT_INIT(510) ["debugInit.c",L500]
JDWP exit error JVMTI_ERROR_INTERNAL(113): No transports initializedERROR: transport error 202: bind failed: Address already in use ["transport.c",L41]
ERROR: JDWP Transport dt_socket failed to initialize, TRANSPORT_INIT(510) ["debugInit.c",L500]
JDWP exit error JVMTI_ERROR_INTERNAL(113): No transports initialized

I'm changing the bug title and severity accordingly.

thanks for your reply rob,

>...liblocalfile_1_0_0.so.  This library provides
platform-specific optimizations for certain file system operations.  This
library is not present on all platforms, so this may not be an error.  The
resources plug-in will safely fall back to using java.io.File functionality.

i read that as, "The resources plug-in will safely fall back to using java.io.File functionality." as the message suggests, i believe the missing liblocalfile_1_0_0.so is not an error; more of a "notice" maybe?.


> The mac issue looks distinct (can you verify that the configured admin URL of
> t3://localhost:7001 for the server instance is valid)


i did a couple things to confirm that t3://localhost:7001 is a valid admin url on the mac:

  1. removed all applications from the server instance under test so that there was nothing to deploy or undeploy 

when there aren't any apps to deploy or undeploy, that "java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused; No available router
to destination." exception is never thrown on the mac. instead, WSLT successfully completes whatever it was commanded to do and the following gets written to the cgServer.log:

=====================================================
...
...<Graceful shutdown of cgServer was issued remotely from 10.0.0.9> 
...<Server shutdown has been requested by weblogic> 
...<Server state changed to SUSPENDING>
... 
... <Server state changed to ADMIN> 
...<Server state changed to SHUTTING_DOWN> 
...
...<Channel "Default[2]" listening on 127.0.0.1:7001 was shutdown.> 
...
=====================================================

  2. changed the protocol of the "adminurl" attrs of the "deploy" and "undeploy" targets of this ant script from "t3" to "http":

  "/Applications/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.weblogic_1.5.1.v200609141504/buildfiles/wldeploy.xml"
  
when there aren't any apps to deploy or undeploy; and the protocol is "t3", all is right with the world. but when the protocol is changed to "http", it chokes regardless (even if "Enable Tunneling" is true).

i haven't checked for sure; but if i'm not mistaken i think that is the same admin url that workshop for weblogic 9.2 uses in its integration with wtp. i am assuming that if that admin url works for workshop 9.2, then it is good to go for eclipse 3.2.2. please, correct me if i'm wrong?

anyway, i think that "java.net.ConnectException" stacktrace is a red herring. i believe it is a _symptom_ of the premature server shutdown; not a cause of the shutdown. i posted it only for the sake of completeness. but of course, i could be totally wrong about that.


> -are you able to successfully launch external Java processed from your Eclipse
> instance? (e.g. another Eclipse instance)

i can confirm that i am able to successfully launch external java processes from both eclipse installations (solaris 9 and os x).

in the main method of a test class, i simply coded 'Runtime.getRuntime().exec("[path to a different eclipse installation]")'; 
then, with that class open in the eclipse 3.2.2 installation's java editor, i right-clicked on the test class and selected "Run As -> Java Application";
and in both cases (on solaris & mac). the instances of the different eclipse installations successfully launched on both os-es.

> -are you able to successfully use any other WTP server adapters?

also able to succesfully start tomcat 5.5 from eclipse 3.2.2/wtp 1.5.4 on solaris (haven't tried it on the mac, but i suspect it would be the same result).there was a minor snag though when i shutdown tomcat from eclipse. but i won't confuse the issue with too many more details.

thanks again for your help, rob.

many thanks,
sun_certified

Per comment #9, I'm going to resolve this as WORKSFORME; please try changing your server timeout delay preference to increase the allowable server timeout:

Window->Preferences->Server->Server timeout delay: "Longer" (Gorkem: appears that PingThread just uses it's internal default if "Unlimited" is specified)

If that doesn't work for you, please reopen

	at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read1(BufferedInputStream.java:253)

One of those property values is "Unlimited", however, the current implementation of the GenericServer PingThread incorrectly uses a default value of "60" pings (equivalent to about 15 seconds) if the ServerType.getStartTimeout() returns -1 (the value for no timeout).

Could still be a timeout issue, however, based on your latest logs, it appears something else is happening; server state changes to RUNNING and the following is logged:

<May 14, 2007 8:50:29 PM BST> <Notice> <Server> <BEA-002613> <Channel "Default" is now listening on 127.0.0.1:7001 for protocols iiop, t3, ldap, http.>

Just to verify, could you try starting that server domain independent from WTP and verifying that you can connect to http://localhost:7001?

You might also want to try things out with a "stripped down" domain (so that it will start up more quickly) to see if in fact the WTP server logic is timing out.

(In reply to comment #20)

See answers below

> thanks rob,
> 
> i'm grateful that i now know what to do to avoid an unwanted shutdown.  am i 
> correct in my understanding that "Resolution: WORKSFORME / Status: RESOLVED" 
> suggests this is not expected to happen to other users under similar
> circumstances? 
> 

It is really "by design"; that particular server domain/machine combination was timing out on startup and, by design, that triggers the execution of the shutdown logic. WTP supports configurable timeout delays (using the preference I mentioned earlier),  and that allows most users to set things appropriately for their environment. In your case, however, you need the "unlimited" delay but that is not supported by the generic server PingThread. That is a separate issue, however, so I opened a new bug.

> the reason i am making extra effort to fully understand this issue, is because 
> as a contractor i work with lots of different dev shops that are _licensed_ bea 
> wls customers; between engagements, i proactively investigate scenarios like 
> the one described in this thread; so that if i encounter similar circumstances
> on a paid engagement i will be that much further ahead of the game.
> 
> for example, say a licensed user's non-workshop _production_ domain has similar
> types and similar amounts of components deployed to it as the bea sample
> wl_server domain has. and say this licensed customer has architectural 
> constraints defined for their production system that dictate they MUST HAVE 
> weblogic server 9.2 mp1 deployed on solaris 9 sparc oe; and say - for whatever
> reason - their developers MUST code, build and deploy using the eclipse 3.2.2 
> ide, with wtp 1.5.4, etc. and say - for whatever reason - eclipse.org's wtp 
> developers can't get around to looking at bug #186902 for six months.  given
> the above constraints, what would bea recommend their licensed wls 9.2 mp1
> customers 
> do if they encounter the timed-out shutdown behavior?
> 

BEA would first recommend the use, where supported, of the custom WLS server adapter bundled with Workshop (we are planning on making that available as a downloadable server adapter for WTP - see Konstantin's note to the mailing list on that topic).

As a general rule, deployment from the IDE should be only performed against development domains; for production domain, users often create a module archive (using command-line build scripts, exporting as an EAR/WAR/JAR from the IDE) and deploy to the production WLS domain via a separate mechanism (script, etc.) once the application has been throughly tested on the development domain. 

Use of external start/stop/deployment tools can be used as a workaround for issues with IDE integration.
